awd_titl_txt: SCH: INT: Collaborative Research: Smart Alarms 2.0: Foundations for Caregiver-in-the-loop Suppression of Non-Informative Alarms
awd_abstract_narration:
Systems used to continuously monitor vital signs in hospitals and home settings generate alarms intended to warn caregivers, clinicians in the hospital, or parents at home of conditions that warrant their immediate attention. However, less than 1% of these alarms are considered actionable or informative, which has led to clinical alarm fatigue being ranged as one of the Top 10 Health Technology Hazards. While there have been advances in human factors, operational factors, and technical factors independently, their interdependencies have yet to be collectively considered. Consequently, current alarm suppression systems aimed at addressing clinical alarm fatigue are generally not extensible, suffer from low adoption rates, and/or have poor performance in practice.

This proposal aims to develop foundations for the design of next generation smart alarms. Smart Alarms 2.0 will utilize caregiver-in-the-loop alarm suppression systems to reduce the frequency of non-informative alarms in-clinic and at home. Realizing an effective caregiver-in-the-loop alarm suppression system requires fundamental advances in robust alarm suppression design methodologies and caregiver-in-the-loop modeling and analysis. The potential impact of the proposed design and analysis techniques is evaluated in medical scenarios for alarm suppression applications, spanning pediatric wards and at-home monitoring of Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) patients. This project will lay the foundations for designing caregiver-in-the-loop alarm systems in which physicians, nurses, and parents monitor the right children, at the right times, using optimal alarm settings to maximize informativeness.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The aim of the project is to develop foundations for the design of next-generation smart alarms – Smart Alarms 2.0 – that utilize caregiver-in-the-loop alarm suppression systems to reduce the frequency of non-informative alarms in-clinic and at home. The key outcomes of the project are fundamental advances in robust alarm suppression design methodologies and caregiver-in-the-loop modeling and analysis based on novel machine learning technologies.

In collaboration with our AHRQ-funded Patient Safety Learning Laboratory and the BPD Saturation TARgeting Trial (BPD STAR), we conducted a cohort study of infants on pulse oximeters, which demonstrated that (a) typical home oximeter settings create an untenable alarm burden for caregivers and (b) adaptive and personalized alarm settings can significantly decrease alarm rates while preserving actionable alarms for episodes of potentially critical hypoxemia.

The key technical outcomes of the project address the challenge of obtaining large amounts of labeled data needed to train smart alarm systems.  The project has developed an adaptive expert-in-the-loop technique based on active learning, which makes infrequent queries to the expert, balancing the load on the expert against the quality of labels.  The evaluation demonstrates increases in labeling accuracy of up to 28% for vital sign time series data and up to 15% for medical images.

Based on these fundamental techniques, the project has developed and released a prototype smart alarm system StrokeDetectAI, available at https://urldefense.com/v3/__http://jamesweimer.net/StrokeDetectAI/__;!!IBzWLUs!Suup_kfhGFt8J9qqIhbLMEar5AMozXG_K6rHJJMApfU6ZJ5KB5cRS3oIkMRf9e6ovONih2cD7DC2legkNYDGPOw$. This software was licensed to Neuralert Technologies and was subsequently identified as a Time Magazine Best Invention of 2022 and designated a "Breakthrough Device" by the US FDA.
